Line 1: Line 1: −
'''Morality''' is a complex system of general principles and particular judgments based on [[cultural]], [[religious]], and [[philosophical]] concepts and beliefs, by which an individual determines whether his or her actions are [[good|right]] or [[evil|wrong]].
+
'''Morality''' is a system of principles and judgments based on [[cultural]], [[religious]], and [[philosophical]] concepts and beliefs, by which humans determine whether given actions are [[good|right]] or [[evil|wrong]].
 
These concepts and beliefs are often generalized and codified by a culture or group, and thus serve to regulate the behaviour of its members.
 
These concepts and beliefs are often generalized and codified by a culture or group, and thus serve to regulate the behaviour of its members.
 
Conformity to such codification may also be called ''morality'', and the group may depend on widespread conformity to such codes for its continued existence.
 
Conformity to such codification may also be called ''morality'', and the group may depend on widespread conformity to such codes for its continued existence.
Line 7: Line 7:      
There is, of course, in any society, a divergence between the notion of how we ought to behave and the reality of how we behave; so there is a difference between hypothetical [[pundit (politics)|pundit]]ry and real morality. He whom we call "moral" is moral only after he behaves in accordance with either (if we take the pluralist stance) our perception of "morality", or (if we accept its existence) in the universal human interest.
 
There is, of course, in any society, a divergence between the notion of how we ought to behave and the reality of how we behave; so there is a difference between hypothetical [[pundit (politics)|pundit]]ry and real morality. He whom we call "moral" is moral only after he behaves in accordance with either (if we take the pluralist stance) our perception of "morality", or (if we accept its existence) in the universal human interest.
